DOC.HEAD: West Steps Up Espionage To Get Grip on New East Germany
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western governments have stepped up intelligence gathering in East Germany to get a grip on the new political situation, the official ADN news agency said Friday. The United States and West Germany are interested especially in acquiring information from political, economic and military sources, the agency said, citing the Agency for Protection of the Constitution, as the country's counterintelligence service is known. The new service, which bears the same name as its West German equivalent, was created when the Stasi _ the hated secret police _ was dissolved and reorganized. Western intelligence agencies are seeking to get a fix on the new leaders who have emerged since the collapse of the Communist Party to be able formulate a new German policy, the agency said. The agencies have concluded that German reunification is on the poltical agenda, but have yet to decide whether German unity is a military danger to European stability or if Western governments should support the rapprochement, ADN said. The ouster of former Communist Party leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18 as well as his successor Egon Krenz on Dec. 3 has pushed little-known groups into the political limelight. The future role of the newly renamed Communist Party remains unclear to the Western agencies, ADN reported. As a result of political fragmentation and the emergence of new political groups, Western intelligence services are trying to recruit new sources on a wider political basis. The creation of a new pool of agents in strategic positions in the government, economy military and security service is of key importance to the West, ADN reported.
